title: Domain 2.8: Given a scenario, use networking tools.
content:
🧰 2.8 – Networking Tools Explained

🔧 Crimper

Used to attach connectors (like RJ-45) to cables.
Example: creating a custom Ethernet cable.

🧠 Tip: Crimps the metal pins down into the wires.

🔪 Cable Stripper

Strips the outer insulation from network cables without damaging inner wires.
Used before crimping or punching down.

🧠 Tip: First step when making your own patch cable.

📶 WiFi Analyzer

App or device that scans wireless networks. Identifies:

  • SSIDs
  • Channel usage
  • Signal strength
  • Interference

🧠 Tip: Used to troubleshoot Wi-Fi dead zones or interference (e.g., overlapping channels).

🔍 Toner Probe (Tone Generator + Probe)

Helps trace cables through walls or patch panels.
Tone generator sends signal; probe “hears” it on the other end.

🧠 Tip: Perfect for finding the other end of a mystery cable.

🔨 Punchdown Tool

Used to terminate wires into patch panels or keystone jacks.
Pushes individual wires into insulation-displacement contacts (IDCs).

🧠 Tip: You'll see this when setting up structured cabling in walls.

✅ Cable Tester

Tests whether a cable is working correctly. Can check for:

  • Shorts
  • Miswires
  • Open pairs

🧠 Tip: If a user reports “no connection” and you suspect the cable, use this.

🔄 Loopback Plug

Small plug that sends data back to the sender.
Used to test network or serial ports.

🧠 Tip: If a NIC is suspect, plug this in to test send/receive.

🕵️ Network Tap

Monitors network traffic by copying data without disrupting flow.
Used in security audits or packet capture tools (like Wireshark).

🧠 Tip: Different from a switch port mirror — taps are hardware-based.
